intro: Seseli cervariifolium, commonly known as the woolly bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of the western United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its finely divided, feathery foliage. The plant produces small, white or pale yellow flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. Its leaves are covered in a dense layer of fine, white hairs, giving it a woolly appearance. Seseli cervariifolium is often found in dry, rocky habitats and is adapted to thrive in high-altitude environments.
